headline.main: Goodbye, Government, Under Either Fiscal Plan
headline.print_headline: Goodbye, Government, Under Either Fiscal Plan

docs.abstract: Eduardo Porter Economic Scene column asserts that contemplated spending cuts in budget deal would roll discretionary spending back to Eisenhower-era levels, gutting services that millions of Americans depend on.

docs.lead_paragraph: The study by the New York City health department, the largest to date, was released mere months after cancer was added to the list of sicknesses covered by the World Trade Center compensation fund.

headline.seo: No Clear Link Between Cancer and 9/11 Debris, New York Health Dept. Study Finds
headline.main: No Clear Link Between Cancer and 9/11 Debris, Study Finds
headline.print_headline: City Study Finds No Clear Link Between 9/11 Debris and Cancer

docs.abstract: New York City Health Dept study to be published in Journal of American Medical Association finds no clear link between cancer and dust, debris and fumes released by burning wreckage of World Trade Center in September 11, 2001, attacks; report casts into doubt decision by federal government to add cancer to list illnesses covered by the James Zadroga 9/11 Health and Compensation Act.
docs.snippet: The study by the New York City health department, the largest to date, was released mere months after cancer was added to the list of sicknesses covered by the World Trade Center compensation fund.

docs.lead_paragraph: Consensus is building around the idea that the largest Medicare savings should come from institutional providers of care.

headline.main: Hospitals Fear They’ll Bear Brunt of Medicare Cuts
headline.print_headline: Search for More Savings in Medicare Now Tackles How Much, and Where

docs.abstract: Cuts to Medicare are almost certain as Pres Obama and Congress try to thrash out a budget deal, but question is how much and who will bear the brunt cuts; consensus is building around the idea that the largest Medicare savings should come from hospitals and other institutional providers of care.
docs.snippet: Consensus is building around the idea that the largest Medicare savings should come from institutional providers of care.

docs.lead_paragraph: The automatic spending cuts would be scary and the hit to the economy severe — but any negotiated deal is sure to be worse.

headline.seo: Forget the Warnings: Let’s Drive Over the Fiscal Cliff!

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by law Prof David A Super dispels misconception that failure to reach negotiated settlement on budgetary changes set to take effect on Jan 1, 2013, will enlarge deficit; says automatic cuts would be far better than any likely deal would be.
docs.snippet: The automatic spending cuts would be scary and the hit to the economy severe — but any negotiated deal is sure to be worse.

headline.main: In the Middle: Why Elderly Couples Fight

docs.abstract: Degenerative relationships are not uncommon among the elderly in even the happiest marriages. Both mental and physical changes feed the discord, marriage therapists and geriatricians say.
